channel.name: Is a token account update approved if a direct or nested child of token owner account update?

messages.content: Yes. In the case of nested, only if the in between updates have isDelegateCall = true
What does isDelegateCall mean in the account update?
You mean semantically, or where to find that field in the account update?
I mean, what is it not in O1JS terms but in raw Mina terms
so semantically maybe
Iirc it's the callType field
And it's an enum of 3 possible values
Call, Delegate_call, No
Call is the default
That's all just off the top of my head though
Thanks I'll look into it
I think you can work around the parent child isuse with this
https://github.com/MinaProtocol/mina/pull/12512

embeds.title: Add `Blind_call` call type by mrmr1993 · Pull Request #12512 · Mina...
embeds.description:
This PR adds the Blind_call call type. To compare the call semantics of this with the others:

Call repesents a plain call, conveying permission to the child (and potentially it's children, via...

messages.content: It's been renamed

may_use_parents_own_token
may_use_token_inherited_from_parent
You can see the stack of callers?
the new names are 10x more confusing...
No you can't see the stack of callers

To expand on the names: The field `mayUseToken` on an account update tells us which token this account update may use. It uses that token by having it in the `tokenId` field.
There are different possibilities:
* an account update can use the token owned by the parent update. In that case it set's `mayUseToken` to `parentsOwnToken` (the parent's own token)
* an AU can inherit the token permission from its parent. (E.g. to use the token owned by its grandparent). In that case it uses `inheritFromParent`
* or an AU restricts itself from using any token other than MINA. In that case, `mayUseToken` = `No`
thanks, makes sense, but it's not clear to me why this field is needed in the first place

> I think you can work around the parent child isuse with this

@Las actually I think there's a way o.O
it's expensive though, but applicable in valuable situations

* situation: contract A wants to call contract B but also, B needs to provably use its caller's (A's) address 
* assume that all contract As in this situation create another account, with their address and the tokenId _they own themselves_
   - that's the expensive part
  - let's call this token account A_t
* then, A calls B and passes its own address as an argument
* B takes that address and creates a child account update for A_t, which has `mayUseToken` = `inheritFromParent` and is otherwise empty
  - this A_t update goes into B's public input. It *has* to be there for B's proof to succeed
 - also, the A_t update needs A to be higher up in the call stack; otherwise Mina rejects with `"Token owner not caller"`
* that means that _only A_ can call B with A's address as argument! => **B has provable access to A's address**

@maht0rz check this out ^^ I know you went back and forth on account update / caller relations
@gregor this kind of thing is very common in Cardano hence why I thought of it
A lot of playing with tokens
I'm not sure you can do anything fundamentally different than this with this trick but you could e.g. also share context across "paths"
e.g. if one leaf wants to tell another leaf something
@gregor Is token owner needed when balance doesn't change?
And what happess if you have two A_t and A'_t as children of B
yes, needed for every account update that has a non-default token id
can you have A and A' both be parents and make it work?
so A -> A' -> B -> {A_t, A'_t}
unfortunately I think no
why?
because there is just 1 token permission "slot" that can be passed down to children
lol
should probably be fixed
unreasonable limitation
so B can *either* have A or A' token permission. Only 1 of them. And pass down only that one to its children
I agree it complicates multi-token designs a LOT
I don't think the may use token stuff makes sense
if at any point in the call stack you have the token owner it should work
if A calls B which transfers tokens of A from C to D, A knows about it inherently
there's no security issue
At what point would you e.g. ever use No/Blind_call?
It doesn't make sense
that one does make sense to me
Just don't validate on an account update that transfers your token
Explain a use case that can't be done without it?
look - a token owner contract may want to enforce that some of its children use "No", so that it doesn't have to worry about what *their* children do with tokens
without restricting them to have 0 children
but the token owner already knows exactly what they do
because the entire hash is public input
it only knows that if they exhibit it in the circuit. and that's expensive! you have to unhash a tree of account updates and process them all
if you call B and don't want it to use weird tokens, look at its source code
you don't need to do weird stuff
that's a misconception now - token contracts are not written with a specific child account update in mind
you already know exactly what B does because you have the source code
wdym?
they are written to approve arbitrary interactions with tokens, as long as those don't violate the token's rules
I realise that
otherwise everything you can do with token accounts would have to exactly be hard-coded in the token contract
hmm I get what you mean
but doesn't it do something similar anyway to check that token balance change is 0?
no! balance check doesn't restrict your grand children AUs to mint infinite tokens

so either exactly prescribe the nested child layout, and check all of them for 0 balance, or do something very complicated with recursive proofs to allow arbitrary child layouts, OR assert that your direct child(ren) use "no"
so that's what token.transfer does?
just sets it to no?
no 😄 that one just hardcodes the account update structure (1 child) so no need for a check like that
so approveUpdate?
and wouldn't it have two children?
one sending one receiving
what I'm describing isn't really reflected in the o1js API right now 😄 the approve stuff with complicated layouts doesn't work atm
but that's the theory 😄
ah ok
so for approving you'd use this?
to avoid having to check the entire thing
if proving wasn't so slow I still think it would be worth it
though that isn't the case right now obviously
working on it 🫡

Hi, I wanna ask if this approach still works after this PR https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1402 ? I'm trying to implement this but the error `"Token owner not caller"` is being thrown despite of having an AU of A higher up the call stack
@gregor may you help me confirm this?
@phn2211 I don't imagine the token contract changes to affect this
thank you, I will try to test this again
Thank you so much!
